Analysis.name: 3rd or 4th degree tears
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Low risk
Randomized by a web-based system. Allocation concealed until after assignment. No concerns regarding baseline characteristics reported in table 3 of the trial report.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: Methods and definitions not stated but tears measured in a standard way. Measurement of the outcome could have been influenced by knowledge of the intervention received but this is unlikely.
Overall.bias.support: Some concerns in measurmenet of the outcome.

Analysis.name: 3rd or 4th degree tears
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Low risk

Randomisation was in a ratio of 1/1 within balanced blocks of 4 to 8, stratified by centre. Details of the allocated group were given on coloured cards contained in sequentially numbered, opaque, sealed envelopes. Randomisation took place at the end of second stage of labour when the midwife considered a vaginal birth was imminent. The two groups were well balanced in respect of socio-demographic characteristics and other prognostic factors at trial entry (Table 1).
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Staff were not blinded but encouraged not to tell women allocation. No deviations reported. ITT used.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: No details given and outcome assessors not blinded. Although the assessment of the outcome could have been influenced by knowledge of the intervention received, it is unlikely as tears are measured in a standard way.
Overall.bias.support: Some concerns in measurement of the outcome and selection of the reported result because of the lack of pre specified details.

Analysis.name: 3rd degree tears
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Low risk

"We randomized women to vocalization or usual care using a list of random numbers generated by a collaborator who was not involved in data collection. Based on this list, we prepared sealed, opaque envelopes numbered one through 40. Each number corresponded to a group allo­cation (experimental or control) which was determined according to the random number sequence. The envelopes were prepared by another collaborator who was also not involved in data collection. Women in the experimental and control group had similar de­mographic and clinical characteristics (Table 1). There was no signifi­cant difference in terms of age, gestational age, years of education, or number of pregnancies."
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Staff not blind. ITT analysis used. No deviations reported.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo:
Tears were defined as: first-degree, involving the skin and/or vaginal mucosa; second-degree, involving the perineal musculature; third- degree, involving the anal sphincter; and fourth-degree, involving the rectal mucosa. The researcher and healthcare provider (nurse or physician) examined the participants after delivery and determined 
which type of perineal tear, if any, had occurred. It is not clear if they were blind to intervention. Assessment of the outcome could have been influenced by knowledge of intervention received but this is unlikely.
Overall.bias.support: Low risk of bias in all domains.

Analysis.name: 3rd or 4th degree tears
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Low risk

"Computer‐generated, ratio 1:1:1 within balanced blocks of 12. Sequentially‐numbered, sealed, opaque envelopes were prepared by the data manager and study administrator and stored in metal box in a restricted area at the hospital's labour unit. The clinical midwife selected the lowest numbered envelope once vaginal birth appeared likely. The envelope contained a card with the study group allocation. When the envelope was drawn, the midwife signed the study register and noted date and time." Randomization produced groups that were evenly matched for all variables. No group differences were statistically significant.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Staff not blind. ITT analysis used. No deviations reported.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: No details given and outcome assessors not blinded. Although the assessment of the outcome could have been influenced by knowledge of the intervention received, it is unlikely as tears are measured in a standard way.
Overall.bias.support: Some concerns in measurement of the outcome and selection of the reported result because of the lack of pre specified details.

Analysis.name: 3rd or 4th degree tears
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Low risk

Randomisation by the National Health and Medical Research Clinical Trials Centre using randomly generated numbers. Sealed, opaque envelopes at the National Health and Medical Research Clinical Trials Centre kept at the neonatal intensive care unit to ensure remote allocation concealment, with randomisation occurring as close as possible to second stage of labour. No concerns regarding baseline characteristics.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Staff not blind. ITT analysis used. No deviations reported.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: An independent, senior midwife blinded to the allocated group was asked to give an independent assessment of the degree of perineal trauma after the birth and whether or not suturing was required. Midwives were instructed not to let other midwives know the allocation.
Overall.bias.support: Some concerns due to selection of the reported result due to lack of prespecified details.

Analysis.name: 3rd or 4th degree tears
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Low risk

Random assignment to the study group was done using a closed envelope that was placed in the medical record and opened at the beginning of the discharge period. Table 1 in the article shows baseline equivalence.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Neither the midwife nor the pregnant woman could be masked to the assigned study group. No deviations reported. No information was available on the analysis.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: No details given and outcome assessors not blinded. Although the assessment of the outcome could have been influenced by knowledge of the intervention received, it is unlikely as tears are measured in a standard way.
Overall.bias.support: Some concerns in deviations of intended interventions, measurement of the outcome and selection of the reported result because of the lack of pre specified details and no details on the analysis.

Analysis.name: 3rd degree tears
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Some concerns
Researchers just state they used simple random sampling. Unsure of method and also concealment.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Staff not blind. ITT analysis used. No deviations reported.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: No details given but missingness unlikely to depend on the outcome.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: No details given and outcome assessors not blinded. Although the assessment of the outcome could have been influenced by knowledge of the intervention received, it is unlikely as tears are measured in a standard way.
Overall.bias.support: Four of the five domains are of some concerns.

Analysis.name: 3rd degree tears
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Some concerns

Article states participants were randomly assigned but method of randomisation and allocation concealment was not clearly described. "The two groups were not signifcantly different in terms of demographic variables (age, post-secondary education and height) (P > 0.05). In terms of pre-pregnancy weight, the control group was signifcantly higher than the massage group (P = 0.014). However, the two groups were not different in terms of weight gain during pregnancy
(P = 0.719). The two groups were also homogenous in terms of gestational age and abortion history (P > 0.05)."
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Staff not blind. ITT analysis used. No deviations reported.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: No details given and outcome assessors not blinded. Although the assessment of the outcome could have been influenced by knowledge of the intervention received, it is unlikely as tears are measured in a standard way.
Overall.bias.support: Some concerns in randomisation, measurement of the outcome and selection of the reported result because of the lack of pre specified details.

Analysis.name: 3rd degree tears
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Low risk

Women who met the criteria were randomised by the attending midwife in one of two ways. At the coordinating centre in hospital 1 a telephone call was made to the emergency department. Here, the duty midwife or clerk opened the next sequentially numbered, double packed, sealed envelope, taken from a box marked either nulliparous or multiparous. For hospitals 2 and 3 the attending midwife opened the next trial envelope from an identical arrangement in the delivery suite. The randomisation schedules and envelopes were prepared in batches of 100 by a research assistant not involved in care of the women. The groups at trial entry were similar in age, parity, previous perineal trauma, and previous operative vagi­nal delivery. In addition, the few women who had used antenatal perineal massage during this pregnancy were equally distributed between groups.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Staff not blind. ITT analysis used. No deviations reported.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: No details given and outcome assessors not blinded. Although the assessment of the outcome could have been influenced by knowledge of the intervention received, it is unlikely as tears are measured in a standard way.
Overall.bias.support: Some concerns in measurement of the outcome and selection of the reported result because of the lack of pre specified details.

Analysis.name: 3rd degree tears
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Low risk

"Numbered sealed opaque envelopes were prepared based on a computer-generated (using random.org) random sequence (within-block, 1:1 ratio) in a random block order 
of 4 or 8 by a co-investigator (PCT) who was not involved in the trial recruitment. The lowest numbered available envelope was 
only assigned to the participant at the point of commencement of pushing (final inclusion criterion) with intention to treat then revealed. Relevant characteristics of participants across the trial arms are similar except for preference for interventions where “fidelity” to eventual allocation was demonstrated."
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Staff not blind. ITT analysis used. No deviations reported.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support:
156/156 available for ITT
119/156 available for PP excluded because of c-section and instrumental deliveries
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: No details given and outcome assessors not blinded. Although the assessment of the outcome could have been influenced by knowledge of the intervention received, it is unlikely as tears are measured in a standard way.
Overall.bias.support: Some concerns in the measurement of the outcome.

Analysis.name: 3rd or 4th degree tears
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Low risk

Co-investigator who was not involved in the trial recruitment prepared the randomised numbered sealed opaque envelopes based on a computer-generated (using random.org) random sequence (within-block, 1 to 1 ratio) and random block order of 4 or 8. Characteristics across trial arms were not different.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Open label, no deviations reported. Modified ITT used.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: 277/281 in modified ITT. 4 excluded due to c section
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: No details given and outcome assessors not blinded. Although the assessment of the outcome could have been influenced by knowledge of the intervention received, it is unlikely as tears are measured in a standard way.
Overall.bias.support: Some concerns in measurement of the outcome.

Analysis.name: 4th degree tears
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Some concerns

The allocated randomisation was registered in an existing clinical data base, containing information of all deliveries at the 2 units. Randomisation was done at the beginning of the second stage of labour (at full cervical dilatation) and allocation took place off site. Midwives phoned up midwives based on different ward who kept randomised number lists for allocation. Not enough detail about the methods in the article.

There were no concern regarding baseline characteristics.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Not possible to blind those delivering the intervention or participants to the intervention. No deviations because of the context of the trial. Intention to treat analysis used.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: 71/767 and 81/808 excluded post-randomsation but ITT analysis conducted before exclusion of operative deliveries
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: Impossible to blind. Delivering midwife assessed tears. No further details given. Assessment of the outcome could have been influenced by knowledge of the intervention received but this is unlikely as tears are measured in a standard way.
Overall.bias.support: Some concerns in randomisation, measurment of the outcome and selection of the reported result due to lack of information.

Analysis.name: 3rd degree tears
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Some concerns

No information on randomisation and allocation concealment. There were no significant differences between the groups regarding maternal age, gestational age, ethnicity, gravidity and parity (Table 1).
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Both oils were contained in similar bottles differentiated only by a number on the bottle. The midwives and the physicians who delivered the parturient were blinded to the oil type. Caregivers were instructed to use the oil during the second stage of the labour (as they routinely do). Method of analysis not stated but number randomised matches the number analysed so we assume ITT was used. No deviations reported.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: No details given and unclear if outcome assessors blinded. Although the assessment of the outcome could have been influenced by knowledge of the intervention received, it is unlikely as tears are measured in a standard way.

Analysis.name: 2nd degree tears
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Low risk

The women were randomly allocated to the intervention or to the control group in an allocation ratio of 1:1 after their midwife opened an opaque sealed envelope in which randomization was revealed. No baseline differences.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: No deviations reported. Not possible to blind. ITT used.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: "Grade of perineal tear, was diagnosed according to ICD-10 classification (O70.0-O70.3) and was based on the examination done by the primary care giver, as is standard practice. The depth of the perineal tear was described (more or less than 50% of the anovaginal distance)." Outcome assessors not blinded. Although the assessment of the outcome could have been influenced by knowledge of the intervention received, it is unlikely as tears are measured in a standard way.
Overall.bias.support: Some concerns in measurment of the outcome.
